item.title: Comment on Friday assorted links by Adam
item.description:
Reply to Hazel Meade:

Being transsexual is objectively "weird" in a way that is completely undeniable. So again I think the Demos are shooting themselves in the foot with this.
More typically in Democratic circles "weird is good". They're all about celebrating weirdness and neurodiversity and all that. So now calling others weird, comes across to me as staged and politically opportunistic. Also wrong in the sense of making "weirdness" a put-down again , which cuts against the thrust of efforts by democrats to be socially inclusive for the last 30 years.

It’s also weird for Vance to wear eyeliner. He’s kind of a transexual-like like that.

item.title: Comment on Friday assorted links by Adam
item.description:
Reply to PHinton:

> Harris appears to be a normal politician.

What part? Demanding we pay the bail for violent criminals so they can visit violence on others? Insisting the border be open? Insisting that people here illegally should get free health care? On top of a $500K education for their K12 kids?

She's weird. The cackle is weird. The repeated words over and over are weird. The lack of accomplishments are weird.

She wants the government to pay for Vance’s eyeliner too. That’s gender affirming care.

item.title: Comment on Friday assorted links by Adam
item.description:
Reply to Restless carrot:

As a non-Westerner my impression is that:

The democrats are like a weird neocommunist party and also very delusional. Their positions regarding economic policy, the culture war, and international relations are all delusional: deeply detached from the physical/social reality on the ground.

Republicans are the party of what I imagine average Americans look like: wearing their denin clothes, beards and everything. While Trump looks like the ultimate American president in terms of appearance and demeanor. He is kinda weird but to me Americans are somewhat weird.

Hanania's argument is based on an anecdote and that is not empirical basis for an argument about weirdness.

In regards, to voting behavior: people vote according to their economic interests. Republicans represent interests of people who pay taxes (middle class and most entrepreneurs) while democrats represent people who live off taxes (urban poor living on welfare and academics and others who work for heavily subsidized industries).

More Americans voted for Biden than Trump in the last election. But the average American is a Trumper? Your schools are failing you. You describe caricatures of Americans that have very little to do with reality.

item.title: Comment on High and low decoupling, and other matters (from my email) by Bob
item.description:
There's a lot of nonsense in there, but my favorite bit is how 'By being egalitarian, the left tolerates a lot of corruption', then supposedly leads to thinking the right doesn't.

I am sorry to say that corruption knows nothing of left or right, equality or inequality. You aren't getting quality institutions by buying what any side sells, and you get massive amounts of state control both ways. It's just a matter of whether the massive state control is going in areas you don't mind it on, or areas where it's really annoying to you.

If you are trying to have even the thinnest grip of reality, you should doubt your friends as much as your foes, and the author here just doesn't really doubt their friends at all.
